bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, November 13, 1944

div1.p: Hench offers to lend Ramos some of his slides which deal with the yellow fever experiments. He also offers financial help to protect Building No. 1 and requests Ramos' assistance in organizing this effort.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, November 13, 1944
div1.opener:
Copies sent to Moran
Rojas
Macia
PSH/cb
also sent Hougontes
Medicos
Ramos
13 November, 1944
Doctor Domingo Ramos
Finlay Institute
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
I was so delighted to meet you again in New York and to know
of your enthusiastic interest in the plans for memorializing Camp Lazear.
I shall be delighted indeed to participate in any of the plans you have
for the immediate future. Also, I will be very glad to read over the
manuscript of your Detroit address. In connection with this address, I
promised to send you a list of the lantern slides which I have been using
for my illustrated lecture on “The Conquest of Yellow Fever”. I have given
this lecture many times in the last four years. I will be glad to lend
you what slides you wish. I don't imagine you will want more than a very
few of them. To show you what the pictures are like, I am sending you
herewith thirty-one photographs of these slides. Unfortunately, I do not
have here in Hot Springs the photographs of the other slides; however,
you may remember that I presented to you, for the Finlay Institute, an
outline of my “proof” of the whereabouts of Camp Lazear. This book I
gave to you and you turned it over to the librarian of the Finlay Institute
in 1941. In this book, you will find many of the other photographs of
which I have had slides made and which are given in this list.

I would appreciate it greatly if you would return to me the
enclosed photographs at your earliest convenience. This is the only set
I have here in Hot Springs and on the back of these photographs are many
notes which I am anxious to keep.

I am sorry I did not get to see you after your chat with
General Kirk, to hear the details of your conversation; however, I am
delighted to know that he seems sympathetic to your plan.

You may remember that I told you I had written John Moran,
asking if he could help me make an arrangement to protect building No.
1. I have not heard from him and I am concerned, lest the recent
hurricane damaged the building. I would appreciate it greatly if, the
next time you see Mr. Marcia, you would discuss this with him briefly,
and I am willing to pay a proper sum, if it is not too great, from the
funds I already have available, in order to preserve the little building
properly. My original idea was to enclose building No. 1 completely
with some sort of strong planking and tar paper so that it would be pro-
tected from the elements, but if there is a chance that there might be
Sheet Two
To: Dr. Domingo Ramos
PSH/cb
13 November 1944
further hurricane between now and the time the little building is
properly enclosed in a permanent building, perhaps it would be better
to surround building No. 1 completely with a more stable structure of
brick, or its equivalent. I am wondering how much it would cost to
erect a brick or concrete enclosure around the building. I am going to
write Mr. Moran, and I know that if he can help you and Mr. Marcia in
any way, he will be glad to do so. I only wish that I were there to
take this burden from you.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M. C.
Chief of the Medical Service
